titleStmt.title: ODD for Objects of the Class 'Corpus' (Metamodel for Corpus Metadata). Version 7.1.

affiliation.affiliation: Institut für deutsche Sprache und Linguistik, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin

sourceDesc.p: Initially created on Tuesday, March 26, 2013 from the form at http://www.tei-c.org.uk/Roma/.

projectDesc.p: LAUDATIO: Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information. The management and archiving of digital research data is an overlapping field for linguistics, library and information science (LIS) and computer science. These disciplines are cooperating in the LAUDATIO project. The name LAUDATIO is an abbreviation for "Long-term Access and Usage of Deeply Annotated Information". The project is funded by the German Research Foundation from 2011-2014 and from 2015-2018.

revisionDesc.change: Updating metadata model and documentation. Correction.
Addition of attribute role value "transcription" for author.
Addition of values for @ident of elementSpec for the annotations in the document. Changing the version number system: change from 0.2 to full counts.
Additions with respect to the documentation part of the ODD.

div.head: Metamodel for Corpus Metadata (MCM)
div.p: The metamodel for corpus metadata refers to all kinds of historical text corpora.

figure.head: Metamodel for corpus metadata. Part of the metamodel with three main classes. A corpus contains one or more documents. A document contains one or more annotations.

div.p: The Metamodel for Corpus Metadata (MCM) models corpus metadata which scientists can use to explore historical corpora in a deeply structured and uniform way. The MCM covers information about annotation categories, concepts and formats, steps taken in preparation of the corpus, such as data and corpus compilation, the documents, and the corpus itself. These metadata are necessary information to ensure the reusability a corpus.

In the MCM there are three main concepts, 'Annotation', 'Document', and 'Corpus', which are modeled as classes in a composition relation. An object of the class 'Document' is a composition of one or more objects of the class 'Annotation'. An object of the class 'Corpus' is a composition of one or more objects of the class 'Document'. For each concept, there is a list of attributes which represent the metadata relevant for documentation. For example, the attribute 'name' is assigned to each object. There is a difference between the title of the corpus, the title of a historical document within the corpus and the title of an annotation layer. With the help of the metamodel, it will become clear which title is meant in which situation.

For detailed information, motivation and discussion see
Odebrecht, Carolin (2015) Interdisziplinäre Nutzung von Forschungsdaten mithilfe einer technisch-abstrakten Modellierung. Vortrag. Von Daten zu Erkenntnissen. 2. Jahrestagung des Verbandes der Digital Humanities im deutschsprachigen Raum. 25.02.-27.02.2015, Graz.
Odebrecht, Carolin (2014) Modeling Linguistic Research Data for a Repository for Historical Corpora. Digital Humanities 2014 Conference. 8.7.-12.7.2014, Lausanne.

div.head: Realisation of the Metamodel for Corpus Metadata
div.p: With the help of three TEI customizations, a TEI scheme is created for each of the objects of the classes 'Corpus', 'Document' and 'Annotation' by mapping the MCM and TEI p5 header structure. The MCM is realized with TEI p5 by using a subset of the TEI p5.

Each TEI XML file contains fileDesc, encodingDesc and revisionDesc. Additionally, the TEI XML files for objects of the classes 'Corpus' and 'Document' contain profileDesc because they refer to the language used in the data.

The headers relate to each other in the following way: The 'Corpus Header' provides lists of documents corresponding to the 'Document Header' and lists of annotations corresponding to the 'PreparationStep Header'. Each 'Document Header' contains a list of annotations for each document in the corpus corresponding to the 'PreparationStep Header'.
This customization refers to the class 'Corpus'.

div.head: Application for the TEI customization for corpus metadata
div.p: The LAUDATIO-Repository provides open access to historical text corpora using metadata such as the corpus title, version, documents in the corpus, formats, annotation and responsible editors, annotators and projects.

The TEI customization provides a metadata scheme for corpus metadata. The TEI scheme is used in the LAUDATIO-Repository to enable a structured and uniform display and facetted and free-text metadata search of corpus metadata.
The metadata are stored in TEI XML for each corpus in the repository . There are three ODDs which specify the metadata for a corpus, the documents of the corpus and the annotation in the documents.
The TEI ODD is developed in the context of the LAUDATIO-Project in cooperation with the working groups of the Search and Visualization System ANNIS and the converter framework SaltNPepper.

div.head: TEI p5 customization for the object of the class 'Corpus'
div.p: The ODD combines the modules textstructure, core, header, tei and namesdates, but removes most of the available elements and changes some attribute concepts, by adding a TEI attribute to an element, for example. Thus, the customization is very restricted and allows little variation in selecting elements and attributes.

div.head: Modules
div.p: The customization includes some elements in the modules. The header module gets additional elements and element groups to increase the information content.

No class or general module modifications were made. The TEI scheme is only locally restricted. That means that no inheritance relations or module relations were changed, deleted or added. The customization is documented in the section 'Formal Declaration'.

All encoded metadata refer to information addressing the whole corpus, such as the editors and annotators of the corpus, the preliminary annotations guidelines used in each format of the corpus, the revision history, the available formats and the license.

div.head: Basic TEI header structure
div.p: The TEI metadata scheme for the objects of the class 'Corpus' contains many more elements and modules compared to a standard TEI headers, which are usually used for the purpose of text documentation only. For validity, fileDesc, the profileDesc, encodingDesc and revisionDesc are required.

The fileDesc contains the following elements where the basic meaning is left untouched but is referred to the object 'Corpus'. For example, the element author refers to the editor of the corpus, the element title refers to the title of the entire corpus. Elements used within teiHeader are:

The titleStmt contains the title, editors, annotators, and technical features of the corpus with the declaration forename, surname and affiliation.
...
... ...
... ...
... ...
... ...

The extent provides information about the size of the corpus. The attribute type defines the counting unit, 'tokens' or 'words'.
...

The publicationStmt covers availability, responsibility, and publication dates.
... ...
....
...
The sourceDesc contains a list of documents of the corpus which are given in technical abbreviations.

The profileDesc contains metadata concerning the language of the corpus data including remarks on language type and language area.
... ... ...

The encodingDesc contains descriptions of the corpus annotation guidelines depending on the format, segmentation, and normalization. Each annotation key and value of each format is listed with a short description extracted from the annotation guidelines. Furthermore, the annotations are roughly divided according to their functions. Additionally, the name of the research project is provided. Elements used within encodingDesc are:
...
...
...
...
...

revisionDesc refers to the version of the corpus. Corpora in the may have several versions. The changes between these versions will be provided here.
... ...

div.head: Detailed TEI header structure
div.p:
A full TEI structure for corpus metadata with all required elements is given below:
...
... ...
... ...
... ...
... ...
...
... ...
....
...
... ... ...
...
...
...
...
...
... ... ...
... ... ...
... ...

moduleRef.include: author editor date list item label p ref title

appInfo application authority availability change editorialDecl encodingDesc extent fileDesc idno langUsage language namespace normalization profileDesc projectDesc publicationStmt revisionDesc segmentation sourceDesc tagUsage tagsDecl teiHeader titleStmt

exemplum.p: The fileDsec refers to the whole corpus. Each corpus has one or more editors and may have additional technical supporters, see editor and author. Project and institution references can be made in affiliation for a person or in publicationStmt in general. All documents of a corpus are listed in sourceDesc with a technical abbreviation.

affiliation.orgName: Institut für deutsche Sprache und Linguistik
Institut für deutsche Sprache und Linguistik

availability.p: Open Source Project. All corpus data generated by the RIDGES project are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.

elementSpec.desc: encoding description contains metadata about the formats and annotations in the corpus. The element encodingDesc refers to the different formats in the corpus. For each format, a single encodingDesc contains information the annotation keys and values.

exemplum.p: For Example: A corpus is available in EXMARaLDA format. The annotations were applied using the EXMARaLDA partiture editor in a certain version, see appInfo. The element segmentation provides information about annotations with the minimal segmentation of the format. The element normalization provides information about normalizations. tagsDecl lists the annotation keys and values which are available in EXMARalDA format. Each namespace has @rend with a fixed set of values which classify the annotation according to their basic functions such as 'Transcription', 'Lexical' and 'Morphological'.

projectDesc.p: The RIDGES project (Register in Diachronic German Science) is an investigation into the development of the German scientific language in the early modern and modern periods, ranging from the mid 16th to the late 19th century.

segmentation.p: Multiple segmentations on the basis of "dipl", "clean" and "norm".

normalization.p: Two normalizations are provided by the layer "clean", containing normalizations of special characters, and by the layer "norm", containing normalizations of orthography.

namespace.name: dipl
namespace.tagUsage: The diplomatic transcription of the word form as found in the manuscript. Line-breaks are marked as in the text, usually as 'U+2E17'.

attDef.gloss: The specification of the ODD refering to the objects of the class 'Corpus'.

valItem.gloss: The title only refers to the metadata object 'Corpus'.

attDef.gloss: Indicate the type of measure you you to inform abput the size of the corpus.

valItem.gloss: The size of the corpus is given in token.
The size of the corpus is given in words.

attDef.gloss: Identify the type of metadata schema: CorpusHeader, DocumentHeader, PreparationHeader

attDef.desc: List of documents in the corpus with corresponding references.

elementSpec.desc: The langUsage defines the language(s) in the corpus.

langUsage.language: Early New High German, Modern German
